item.title: Spritpreise: Implementing a price alarm backend
item.description:
Spritpreise has recently a Price Alarm feature, that sends push notifications based on a personal price threshold. In this blog post, I’ll explain some of the technical details and considerations that went into the implementation.

The API

The price alarm is handled by a new application and API that I have implemented based on the Spring Boot / Kotlin stack. It uses a database to store the configured price alarms, stations as well as the Firebase Cloud Messaging push token.

item.title: Spritpreise: Price alarm now available
item.description:
Spritpreise has received a useful new feature ‚Äì the Price Alarm! Starting now, you can set a personal price threshold for your favorite gas stations. If the price for Super E5, E10, or Diesel drops below this value, you’ll automatically receive a push notification directly to your smartphone.

You’re on vacation or have recently filled up? No worries, pause the price alarm with one simple click for a few hours or days - until you need it again.

item.title: Dino World Run: Moving world
item.description: In a game, the player normally moves through the world. This works perfectly for the vast majority of games, but for endless runners this can lead to problems if the coordinates where the player is located encounter floating point errors. Admittedly, most players will probably never have a run that long before this becomes a problem, but the theoretical possibility of this alone interested me. How frustrating would it be if you had a mega run and then the game crashed or glitched?
